main event: An orange object was observed descending on a slight dive, firing pockets, and then disappearing over Love Field in Dallas, Texas.
interesting points: Observed by unidentified flight personnel at Love Field in Dallas, Texas on October 26, 1952 at 21:30 CST.
The orange object appeared to leave a trail similar to an afterburner exhaust, descended on a flight path from southeast to northwest, and then disappeared after seeming to fire a number of rockets.

The sighting lasted approximately 2.5 minutes and was visually witnessed by First Lieutenant Walter H. Baxter, III, a rated pilot on flying status, and Dr. and Mrs. from Arlington State College, Arlington, Texas. Both witnesses were considered reliable.
The object was described as oval in shape, metallic in appearance, and silent in flight, traveling at an estimated speed of 600 MPH at an altitude of 10,000 feet.

The observer, 1st Lt. Walter H. Baxter, Jr., noted that the object had no visible means of propulsion, no sound was heard, and its flight path and speed precluded the possibility of it being a conventional aircraft.
sighted object: orange object descending on a slight dive, firing pockets, and disappearing
witnesses: Unidentified flight personnel, First Lieutenant Walter H. Baxter, III, and Dr. and Mrs. from Arlington State College, Arlington, Texas
